145/*
146 * Start WinSock.
147 * Exported in case some applications using WinPcap called it,
148 * even though it wasn't exported.
149 */
150int
151wsockinit(void)
152{
153 WORD wVersionRequested;
154 WSADATA wsaData;
155 static int err = -1;
156 static int done = 0;
157
158 if (done)
159 return (err);
160
161 wVersionRequested = MAKEWORD( 1, 1);
162 err = WSAStartup( wVersionRequested, &wsaData );
163 atexit ((void(*)(void))WSACleanup);
164 done = 1;
165
166 if ( err != 0 )
167 err = -1;
168 return (err);
169}
170
171/*
172 * This is the exported function; new programs should call this.
173 */
174int
175pcap_wsockinit(void)
176{
177 return (wsockinit());
178}
179#endif /* _WIN32 */

181/*
182 * String containing the library version.
183 * Not explicitly exported via a header file - the right API to use
184 * is pcap_lib_version() - but some programs included it, so we
185 * provide it.
186 *
187 * We declare it here, right before defining it, to squelch any
188 * warnings we might get from compilers about the lack of a
189 * declaration.
190 */
191PCAP_API char pcap_version[];
192PCAP_API_DEF char pcap_version[] = PACKAGE_VERSION;
193
194static int
195pcap_not_initialized(pcap_t *pcap)
196{
197 if (pcap->activated) {
198 /* A module probably forgot to set the function pointer */
199 (void)pcap_snprintf(pcap->errbuf, sizeof(pcap->errbuf),
200 "This operation isn't properly handled by that device");
201 return (PCAP_ERROR);
202 }
203 /* in case the caller doesn't check for PCAP_ERROR_NOT_ACTIVATED */
204 (void)pcap_snprintf(pcap->errbuf, sizeof(pcap->errbuf),
205 "This handle hasn't been activated yet");
206 /* this means 'not initialized' */
207 return (PCAP_ERROR_NOT_ACTIVATED);
208}
209
210#ifdef _WIN32
211static void *
212pcap_not_initialized_ptr(pcap_t *pcap)
213{
214 if (pcap->activated) {
215 /* A module probably forgot to set the function pointer */
216 (void)pcap_snprintf(pcap->errbuf, sizeof(pcap->errbuf),
217 "This operation isn't properly handled by that device");
218 return (NULL);
219 }
220 (void)pcap_snprintf(pcap->errbuf, sizeof(pcap->errbuf),
221 "This handle hasn't been activated yet");
222 return (NULL);
223}
224
225static HANDLE
226pcap_getevent_not_initialized(pcap_t *pcap)
227{
228 if (pcap->activated) {
229 /* A module probably forgot to set the function pointer */
230 (void)pcap_snprintf(pcap->errbuf, sizeof(pcap->errbuf),
231 "This operation isn't properly handled by that device");
232 return (INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE);
233 }
234 (void)pcap_snprintf(pcap->errbuf, sizeof(pcap->errbuf),
235 "This handle hasn't been activated yet");
236 return (INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE);
237}
238
239static u_int
240pcap_sendqueue_transmit_not_initialized(pcap_t *pcap, pcap_send_queue* queue, int sync)
241{
242 if (pcap->activated) {
243 /* A module probably forgot to set the function pointer */
244 (void)pcap_snprintf(pcap->errbuf, sizeof(pcap->errbuf),
245 "This operation isn't properly handled by that device");
246 return (0);
247 }
248 (void)pcap_snprintf(pcap->errbuf, sizeof(pcap->errbuf),
249 "This handle hasn't been activated yet");
250 return (0);
251}

256 if (pcap->activated) {
257 /* A module probably forgot to set the function pointer */
258 (void)pcap_snprintf(pcap->errbuf, sizeof(pcap->errbuf),
259 "This operation isn't properly handled by that device");
260 return (NULL);
261 }
262 (void)pcap_snprintf(pcap->errbuf, sizeof(pcap->errbuf),
263 "This handle hasn't been activated yet");
264 return (NULL);
265}

268/*
269 * Returns 1 if rfmon mode can be set on the pcap_t, 0 if it can't,
270 * a PCAP_ERROR value on an error.
271 */
272int
273pcap_can_set_rfmon(pcap_t *p)
274{
275 return (p->can_set_rfmon_op(p));
276}
277
278/*
279 * For systems where rfmon mode is never supported.
280 */
281static int
282pcap_cant_set_rfmon(pcap_t *p _U_)
283{
284 return (0);
285}
286
287/*
288 * Sets *tstamp_typesp to point to an array 1 or more supported time stamp
289 * types; the return value is the number of supported time stamp types.
290 * The list should be freed by a call to pcap_free_tstamp_types() when
291 * you're done with it.
292 *
293 * A return value of 0 means "you don't get a choice of time stamp type",
294 * in which case *tstamp_typesp is set to null.
295 *
296 * PCAP_ERROR is returned on error.
297 */
298int
299pcap_list_tstamp_types(pcap_t *p, int **tstamp_typesp)
300{
301 if (p->tstamp_type_count == 0) {
302 /*
303 * We don't support multiple time stamp types.
304 */
305 *tstamp_typesp = NULL;
306 } else {
307 *tstamp_typesp = (int*)calloc(sizeof(**tstamp_typesp),
308 p->tstamp_type_count);
309 if (*tstamp_typesp == NULL) {
310 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(p->errbuf, sizeof(p->errbuf),
311 errno, "malloc");
312 return (PCAP_ERROR);
313 }
314 (void)memcpy(*tstamp_typesp, p->tstamp_type_list,
315 sizeof(**tstamp_typesp) * p->tstamp_type_count);
316 }
317 return (p->tstamp_type_count);
318}
319
320/*
321 * In Windows, you might have a library built with one version of the
322 * C runtime library and an application built with another version of
323 * the C runtime library, which means that the library might use one
324 * version of malloc() and free() and the application might use another
325 * version of malloc() and free(). If so, that means something
326 * allocated by the library cannot be freed by the application, so we
327 * need to have a pcap_free_tstamp_types() routine to free up the list
328 * allocated by pcap_list_tstamp_types(), even though it's just a wrapper
329 * around free().
330 */
331void
332pcap_free_tstamp_types(int *tstamp_type_list)
333{
334 free(tstamp_type_list);
335}
336
337/*
338 * Default one-shot callback; overridden for capture types where the
339 * packet data cannot be guaranteed to be available after the callback
340 * returns, so that a copy must be made.
341 */
342void
343pcap_oneshot(u_char *user, const struct pcap_pkthdr *h, const u_char *pkt)
344{
345 struct oneshot_userdata *sp = (struct oneshot_userdata *)user;
346
347 *sp->hdr = *h;
348 *sp->pkt = pkt;
349}
350
351const u_char *
352pcap_next(pcap_t *p, struct pcap_pkthdr *h)
353{
354 struct oneshot_userdata s;
355 const u_char *pkt;
356
357 s.hdr = h;
358 s.pkt = &pkt;
359 s.pd = p;
360 if (pcap_dispatch(p, 1, p->oneshot_callback, (u_char *)&s) <= 0)
361 return (0);
362 return (pkt);
363}
364
365int
366pcap_next_ex(pcap_t *p, struct pcap_pkthdr **pkt_header,
367 const u_char **pkt_data)
368{
369 struct oneshot_userdata s;
370
371 s.hdr = &p->pcap_header;
372 s.pkt = pkt_data;
373 s.pd = p;
374
375 /* Saves a pointer to the packet headers */
376 *pkt_header= &p->pcap_header;
377
378 if (p->rfile != NULL) {
379 int status;
380
381 /* We are on an offline capture */
382 status = pcap_offline_read(p, 1, p->oneshot_callback,
383 (u_char *)&s);
384
385 /*
386 * Return codes for pcap_offline_read() are:
387 * - 0: EOF
388 * - -1: error
389 * - >1: OK
390 * The first one ('0') conflicts with the return code of
391 * 0 from pcap_read() meaning "no packets arrived before
392 * the timeout expired", so we map it to -2 so you can
393 * distinguish between an EOF from a savefile and a
394 * "no packets arrived before the timeout expired, try
395 * again" from a live capture.
396 */
397 if (status == 0)
398 return (-2);
399 else
400 return (status);
401 }
402
403 /*
404 * Return codes for pcap_read() are:
405 * - 0: timeout
406 * - -1: error
407 * - -2: loop was broken out of with pcap_breakloop()
408 * - >1: OK
409 * The first one ('0') conflicts with the return code of 0 from
410 * pcap_offline_read() meaning "end of file".
411 */
412 return (p->read_op(p, 1, p->oneshot_callback, (u_char *)&s));
413}
414
415/*
416 * Implementation of a pcap_if_list_t.
417 */
418struct pcap_if_list {
419 pcap_if_t *beginning;
420};
421
422static struct capture_source_type {
423 int (*findalldevs_op)(pcap_if_list_t *, char *);
424 pcap_t *(*create_op)(const char *, char *, int *);
425} capture_source_types[] = {
426#ifdef HAVE_DAG_API
427 { dag_findalldevs, dag_create },
428#endif
429#ifdef HAVE_SEPTEL_API
430 { septel_findalldevs, septel_create },
431#endif
432#ifdef HAVE_SNF_API
433 { snf_findalldevs, snf_create },
434#endif
435#ifdef HAVE_TC_API
436 { TcFindAllDevs, TcCreate },
437#endif
438#ifdef PCAP_SUPPORT_BT
439 { bt_findalldevs, bt_create },
440#endif
441#ifdef PCAP_SUPPORT_BT_MONITOR
442 { bt_monitor_findalldevs, bt_monitor_create },
443#endif
444#ifdef PCAP_SUPPORT_USB
445 { usb_findalldevs, usb_create },
446#endif
447#ifdef PCAP_SUPPORT_NETFILTER
448 { netfilter_findalldevs, netfilter_create },
449#endif
450#ifdef PCAP_SUPPORT_NETMAP
451 { pcap_netmap_findalldevs, pcap_netmap_create },
452#endif
453#ifdef PCAP_SUPPORT_DBUS
454 { dbus_findalldevs, dbus_create },
455#endif
456#ifdef PCAP_SUPPORT_RDMASNIFF
457 { rdmasniff_findalldevs, rdmasniff_create },
458#endif
459 { NULL, NULL }
460};
461
462/*
463 * Get a list of all capture sources that are up and that we can open.
464 * Returns -1 on error, 0 otherwise.
465 * The list, as returned through "alldevsp", may be null if no interfaces
466 * were up and could be opened.
467 */
468int
469pcap_findalldevs(pcap_if_t **alldevsp, char *errbuf)
470{
471 size_t i;
472 pcap_if_list_t devlist;
473
474 /*
475 * Find all the local network interfaces on which we
476 * can capture.
477 */
478 devlist.beginning = NULL;
479 if (pcap_platform_finddevs(&devlist, errbuf) == -1) {
480 /*
481 * Failed - free all of the entries we were given
482 * before we failed.
483 */
484 if (devlist.beginning != NULL)
485 pcap_freealldevs(devlist.beginning);
486 *alldevsp = NULL;
487 return (-1);
488 }
489
490 /*
491 * Ask each of the non-local-network-interface capture
492 * source types what interfaces they have.
493 */
494 for (i = 0; capture_source_types[i].findalldevs_op != NULL; i++) {
495 if (capture_source_types[i].findalldevs_op(&devlist, errbuf) == -1) {
496 /*
497 * We had an error; free the list we've been
498 * constructing.
499 */
500 if (devlist.beginning != NULL)
501 pcap_freealldevs(devlist.beginning);
502 *alldevsp = NULL;
503 return (-1);
504 }
505 }
506
507 /*
508 * Return the first entry of the list of all devices.
509 */
510 *alldevsp = devlist.beginning;
511 return (0);
512}
513
514static struct sockaddr *
515dup_sockaddr(struct sockaddr *sa, size_t sa_length)
516{
517 struct sockaddr *newsa;
518
519 if ((newsa = malloc(sa_length)) == NULL)
520 return (NULL);
521 return (memcpy(newsa, sa, sa_length));
522}
523
524/*
525 * Construct a "figure of merit" for an interface, for use when sorting
526 * the list of interfaces, in which interfaces that are up are superior
527 * to interfaces that aren't up, interfaces that are up and running are
528 * superior to interfaces that are up but not running, and non-loopback
529 * interfaces that are up and running are superior to loopback interfaces,
530 * and interfaces with the same flags have a figure of merit that's higher
531 * the lower the instance number.
532 *
533 * The goal is to try to put the interfaces most likely to be useful for
534 * capture at the beginning of the list.
535 *
536 * The figure of merit, which is lower the "better" the interface is,
537 * has the uppermost bit set if the interface isn't running, the bit
538 * below that set if the interface isn't up, the bit below that set
539 * if the interface is a loopback interface, and the interface index
540 * in the 29 bits below that. (Yes, we assume u_int is 32 bits.)
541 */
542static u_int
543get_figure_of_merit(pcap_if_t *dev)
544{
545 const char *cp;
546 u_int n;
547
548 if (strcmp(dev->name, "any") == 0) {
549 /*
550 * Give the "any" device an artificially high instance
551 * number, so it shows up after all other non-loopback
552 * interfaces.
553 */
554 n = 0x1FFFFFFF; /* 29 all-1 bits */
555 } else {
556 /*
557 * A number at the end of the device name string is
558 * assumed to be an instance number. Add 1 to the
559 * instance number, and use 0 for "no instance
560 * number", so we don't put "no instance number"
561 * devices and "instance 0" devices together.
562 */
563 cp = dev->name + strlen(dev->name) - 1;
564 while (cp-1 >= dev->name && *(cp-1) >= '0' && *(cp-1) <= '9')
565 cp--;
566 if (*cp >= '0' && *cp <= '9')
567 n = atoi(cp) + 1;
568 else
569 n = 0;
570 }
571 if (!(dev->flags & PCAP_IF_RUNNING))
572 n |= 0x80000000;
573 if (!(dev->flags & PCAP_IF_UP))
574 n |= 0x40000000;
575
576 /*
577 * Give non-wireless interfaces that aren't disconnected a better
578 * figure of merit than interfaces that are disconnected, as
579 * "disconnected" should indicate that the interface isn't
580 * plugged into a network and thus won't give you any traffic.
581 *
582 * For wireless interfaces, it means "associated with a network",
583 * which we presume not to necessarily prevent capture, as you
584 * might run the adapter in some flavor of monitor mode.
585 */
586 if (!(dev->flags & PCAP_IF_WIRELESS) &&
587 (dev->flags & PCAP_IF_CONNECTION_STATUS) == PCAP_IF_CONNECTION_STATUS_DISCONNECTED)
588 n |= 0x20000000;
589
590 /*
591 * Sort loopback devices after non-loopback devices, *except* for
592 * disconnected devices.
593 */
594 if (dev->flags & PCAP_IF_LOOPBACK)
595 n |= 0x10000000;
596
597 return (n);
598}
599
600#ifndef _WIN32
601/*
602 * Try to get a description for a given device.
603 * Returns a mallocated description if it could and NULL if it couldn't.
604 *
605 * XXX - on FreeBSDs that support it, should it get the sysctl named
606 * "dev.{adapter family name}.{adapter unit}.%desc" to get a description
607 * of the adapter? Note that "dev.an.0.%desc" is "Aironet PC4500/PC4800"
608 * with my Cisco 350 card, so the name isn't entirely descriptive. The
609 * "dev.an.0.%pnpinfo" has a better description, although one might argue
610 * that the problem is really a driver bug - if it can find out that it's
611 * a Cisco 340 or 350, rather than an old Aironet card, it should use
612 * that in the description.
613 *
614 * Do NetBSD, DragonflyBSD, or OpenBSD support this as well? FreeBSD
615 * and OpenBSD let you get a description, but it's not generated by the OS,
616 * it's set with another ioctl that ifconfig supports; we use that to get
617 * a description in FreeBSD and OpenBSD, but if there is no such
618 * description available, it still might be nice to get some description
619 * string based on the device type or something such as that.
620 *
621 * In macOS, the System Configuration framework can apparently return
622 * names in 10.4 and later.
623 *
624 * It also appears that freedesktop.org's HAL offers an "info.product"
625 * string, but the HAL specification says it "should not be used in any
626 * UI" and "subsystem/capability specific properties" should be used
627 * instead and, in any case, I think HAL is being deprecated in
628 * favor of other stuff such as DeviceKit. DeviceKit doesn't appear
629 * to have any obvious product information for devices, but maybe
630 * I haven't looked hard enough.
631 *
632 * Using the System Configuration framework, or HAL, or DeviceKit, or
633 * whatever, would require that libpcap applications be linked with
634 * the frameworks/libraries in question. That shouldn't be a problem
635 * for programs linking with the shared version of libpcap (unless
636 * you're running on AIX - which I think is the only UN*X that doesn't
637 * support linking a shared library with other libraries on which it
638 * depends, and having an executable linked only with the first shared
639 * library automatically pick up the other libraries when started -
640 * and using HAL or whatever). Programs linked with the static
641 * version of libpcap would have to use pcap-config with the --static
642 * flag in order to get the right linker flags in order to pick up
643 * the additional libraries/frameworks; those programs need that anyway
644 * for libpcap 1.1 and beyond on Linux, as, by default, it requires
645 * -lnl.
646 *
647 * Do any other UN*Xes, or desktop environments support getting a
648 * description?
649 */
650static char *
651#ifdef SIOCGIFDESCR
652get_if_description(const char *name)
653{
654 char *description = NULL;
655 int s;
656 struct ifreq ifrdesc;
657#ifndef IFDESCRSIZE
658 size_t descrlen = 64;
659#else
660 size_t descrlen = IFDESCRSIZE;
661#endif /* IFDESCRSIZE */
662
663 /*
664 * Get the description for the interface.
665 */
666 memset(&ifrdesc, 0, sizeof ifrdesc);
667 strlcpy(ifrdesc.ifr_name, name, sizeof ifrdesc.ifr_name);
668 s = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_DGRAM, 0);
669 if (s >= 0) {
670#ifdef __FreeBSD__
671 /*
672 * On FreeBSD, if the buffer isn't big enough for the
673 * description, the ioctl succeeds, but the description
674 * isn't copied, ifr_buffer.length is set to the description
675 * length, and ifr_buffer.buffer is set to NULL.
676 */
677 for (;;) {
678 free(description);
679 if ((description = malloc(descrlen)) != NULL) {
680 ifrdesc.ifr_buffer.buffer = description;
681 ifrdesc.ifr_buffer.length = descrlen;
682 if (ioctl(s, SIOCGIFDESCR, &ifrdesc) == 0) {
683 if (ifrdesc.ifr_buffer.buffer ==
684 description)
685 break;
686 else
687 descrlen = ifrdesc.ifr_buffer.length;
688 } else {
689 /*
690 * Failed to get interface description.
691 */
692 free(description);
693 description = NULL;
694 break;
695 }
696 } else
697 break;
698 }
699#else /* __FreeBSD__ */
700 /*
701 * The only other OS that currently supports
702 * SIOCGIFDESCR is OpenBSD, and it has no way
703 * to get the description length - it's clamped
704 * to a maximum of IFDESCRSIZE.
705 */
706 if ((description = malloc(descrlen)) != NULL) {
707 ifrdesc.ifr_data = (caddr_t)description;
708 if (ioctl(s, SIOCGIFDESCR, &ifrdesc) != 0) {
709 /*
710 * Failed to get interface description.
711 */
712 free(description);
713 description = NULL;
714 }
715 }
716#endif /* __FreeBSD__ */
717 close(s);
718 if (description != NULL && strlen(description) == 0) {
719 /*
720 * Description is empty, so discard it.
721 */
722 free(description);
723 description = NULL;
724 }
725 }
726
727#ifdef __FreeBSD__
728 /*
729 * For FreeBSD, if we didn't get a description, and this is
730 * a device with a name of the form usbusN, label it as a USB
731 * bus.
732 */
733 if (description == NULL) {
734 if (strncmp(name, "usbus", 5) == 0) {
735 /*
736 * OK, it begins with "usbus".
737 */
738 long busnum;
739 char *p;
740
741 errno = 0;
742 busnum = strtol(name + 5, &p, 10);
743 if (errno == 0 && p != name + 5 && *p == '\0' &&
744 busnum >= 0 && busnum <= INT_MAX) {
745 /*
746 * OK, it's a valid number that's not
747 * bigger than INT_MAX. Construct
748 * a description from it.
749 */
750 static const char descr_prefix[] = "USB bus number ";
751 size_t descr_size;
752
753 /*
754 * Allow enough room for a 32-bit bus number.
755 * sizeof (descr_prefix) includes the
756 * terminating NUL.
757 */
758 descr_size = sizeof (descr_prefix) + 10;
759 description = malloc(descr_size);
760 if (description != NULL) {
761 pcap_snprintf(description, descr_size,
762 "%s%ld", descr_prefix, busnum);
763 }
764 }
765 }
766 }
767#endif
768 return (description);
769#else /* SIOCGIFDESCR */
770get_if_description(const char *name _U_)
771{
772 return (NULL);
773#endif /* SIOCGIFDESCR */
774}
775
776/*
777 * Look for a given device in the specified list of devices.
778 *
779 * If we find it, return a pointer to its entry.
780 *
781 * If we don't find it, attempt to add an entry for it, with the specified
782 * IFF_ flags and description, and, if that succeeds, return a pointer to
783 * the new entry, otherwise return NULL and set errbuf to an error message.
784 */
785pcap_if_t *
786find_or_add_if(pcap_if_list_t *devlistp, const char *name,
787 bpf_u_int32 if_flags, get_if_flags_func get_flags_func, char *errbuf)
788{
789 bpf_u_int32 pcap_flags;
790
791 /*
792 * Convert IFF_ flags to pcap flags.
793 */
794 pcap_flags = 0;
795#ifdef IFF_LOOPBACK
796 if (if_flags & IFF_LOOPBACK)
797 pcap_flags |= PCAP_IF_LOOPBACK;
798#else
799 /*
800 * We don't have IFF_LOOPBACK, so look at the device name to
801 * see if it looks like a loopback device.
802 */
803 if (name[0] == 'l' && name[1] == 'o' &&
804 (isdigit((unsigned char)(name[2])) || name[2] == '\0')
805 pcap_flags |= PCAP_IF_LOOPBACK;
806#endif
807#ifdef IFF_UP
808 if (if_flags & IFF_UP)
809 pcap_flags |= PCAP_IF_UP;
810#endif
811#ifdef IFF_RUNNING
812 if (if_flags & IFF_RUNNING)
813 pcap_flags |= PCAP_IF_RUNNING;
814#endif
815
816 /*
817 * Attempt to find an entry for this device; if we don't find one,
818 * attempt to add one.
819 */
820 return (find_or_add_dev(devlistp, name, pcap_flags,
821 get_flags_func, get_if_description(name), errbuf));
822}
823
824/*
825 * Look for a given device in the specified list of devices.
826 *
827 * If we find it, then, if the specified address isn't null, add it to
828 * the list of addresses for the device and return 0.
829 *
830 * If we don't find it, attempt to add an entry for it, with the specified
831 * IFF_ flags and description, and, if that succeeds, add the specified
832 * address to its list of addresses if that address is non-null, and
833 * return 0, otherwise return -1 and set errbuf to an error message.
834 *
835 * (We can get called with a null address because we might get a list
836 * of interface name/address combinations from the underlying OS, with
837 * the address being absent in some cases, rather than a list of
838 * interfaces with each interface having a list of addresses, so this
839 * call may be the only call made to add to the list, and we want to
840 * add interfaces even if they have no addresses.)
841 */
842int
843add_addr_to_if(pcap_if_list_t *devlistp, const char *name,
844 bpf_u_int32 if_flags, get_if_flags_func get_flags_func,
845 struct sockaddr *addr, size_t addr_size,
846 struct sockaddr *netmask, size_t netmask_size,
847 struct sockaddr *broadaddr, size_t broadaddr_size,
848 struct sockaddr *dstaddr, size_t dstaddr_size,
849 char *errbuf)
850{
851 pcap_if_t *curdev;
852
853 /*
854 * Check whether the device exists and, if not, add it.
855 */
856 curdev = find_or_add_if(devlistp, name, if_flags, get_flags_func,
857 errbuf);
858 if (curdev == NULL) {
859 /*
860 * Error - give up.
861 */
862 return (-1);
863 }
864
865 if (addr == NULL) {
866 /*
867 * There's no address to add; this entry just meant
868 * "here's a new interface".
869 */
870 return (0);
871 }
872
873 /*
874 * "curdev" is an entry for this interface, and we have an
875 * address for it; add an entry for that address to the
876 * interface's list of addresses.
877 */
878 return (add_addr_to_dev(curdev, addr, addr_size, netmask,
879 netmask_size, broadaddr, broadaddr_size, dstaddr,
880 dstaddr_size, errbuf));
881}
882#endif /* _WIN32 */
883
884/*
885 * Add an entry to the list of addresses for an interface.
886 * "curdev" is the entry for that interface.
887 */
888int
889add_addr_to_dev(pcap_if_t *curdev,
890 struct sockaddr *addr, size_t addr_size,
891 struct sockaddr *netmask, size_t netmask_size,
892 struct sockaddr *broadaddr, size_t broadaddr_size,
893 struct sockaddr *dstaddr, size_t dstaddr_size,
894 char *errbuf)
895{
896 pcap_addr_t *curaddr, *prevaddr, *nextaddr;
897
898 /*
899 * Allocate the new entry and fill it in.
900 */
901 curaddr = (pcap_addr_t *)malloc(sizeof(pcap_addr_t));
902 if (curaddr == NULL) {
903 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
904 errno, "malloc");
905 return (-1);
906 }
907
908 curaddr->next = NULL;
909 if (addr != NULL && addr_size != 0) {
910 curaddr->addr = (struct sockaddr *)dup_sockaddr(addr, addr_size);
911 if (curaddr->addr == NULL) {
912 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
913 errno, "malloc");
914 free(curaddr);
915 return (-1);
916 }
917 } else
918 curaddr->addr = NULL;
919
920 if (netmask != NULL && netmask_size != 0) {
921 curaddr->netmask = (struct sockaddr *)dup_sockaddr(netmask, netmask_size);
922 if (curaddr->netmask == NULL) {
923 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
924 errno, "malloc");
925 if (curaddr->addr != NULL)
926 free(curaddr->addr);
927 free(curaddr);
928 return (-1);
929 }
930 } else
931 curaddr->netmask = NULL;
932
933 if (broadaddr != NULL && broadaddr_size != 0) {
934 curaddr->broadaddr = (struct sockaddr *)dup_sockaddr(broadaddr, broadaddr_size);
935 if (curaddr->broadaddr == NULL) {
936 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
937 errno, "malloc");
938 if (curaddr->netmask != NULL)
939 free(curaddr->netmask);
940 if (curaddr->addr != NULL)
941 free(curaddr->addr);
942 free(curaddr);
943 return (-1);
944 }
945 } else
946 curaddr->broadaddr = NULL;
947
948 if (dstaddr != NULL && dstaddr_size != 0) {
949 curaddr->dstaddr = (struct sockaddr *)dup_sockaddr(dstaddr, dstaddr_size);
950 if (curaddr->dstaddr == NULL) {
951 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
952 errno, "malloc");
953 if (curaddr->broadaddr != NULL)
954 free(curaddr->broadaddr);
955 if (curaddr->netmask != NULL)
956 free(curaddr->netmask);
957 if (curaddr->addr != NULL)
958 free(curaddr->addr);
959 free(curaddr);
960 return (-1);
961 }
962 } else
963 curaddr->dstaddr = NULL;
964
965 /*
966 * Find the end of the list of addresses.
967 */
968 for (prevaddr = curdev->addresses; prevaddr != NULL; prevaddr = nextaddr) {
969 nextaddr = prevaddr->next;
970 if (nextaddr == NULL) {
971 /*
972 * This is the end of the list.
973 */
974 break;
975 }
976 }
977
978 if (prevaddr == NULL) {
979 /*
980 * The list was empty; this is the first member.
981 */
982 curdev->addresses = curaddr;
983 } else {
984 /*
985 * "prevaddr" is the last member of the list; append
986 * this member to it.
987 */
988 prevaddr->next = curaddr;
989 }
990
991 return (0);
992}
993
994/*
995 * Look for a given device in the specified list of devices.
996 *
997 * If we find it, return 0 and set *curdev_ret to point to it.
998 *
999 * If we don't find it, attempt to add an entry for it, with the specified
1000 * flags and description, and, if that succeeds, return 0, otherwise
1001 * return -1 and set errbuf to an error message.
1002 */
1003pcap_if_t *
1004find_or_add_dev(pcap_if_list_t *devlistp, const char *name, bpf_u_int32 flags,
1005 get_if_flags_func get_flags_func, const char *description, char *errbuf)
1006{
1007 pcap_if_t *curdev;
1008
1009 /*
1010 * Is there already an entry in the list for this device?
1011 */
1012 curdev = find_dev(devlistp, name);
1013 if (curdev != NULL) {
1014 /*
1015 * Yes, return it.
1016 */
1017 return (curdev);
1018 }
1019
1020 /*
1021 * No, we didn't find it.
1022 */
1023
1024 /*
1025 * Try to get additional flags for the device.
1026 */
1027 if ((*get_flags_func)(name, &flags, errbuf) == -1) {
1028 /*
1029 * Failed.
1030 */
1031 return (NULL);
1032 }
1033
1034 /*
1035 * Now, try to add it to the list of devices.
1036 */
1037 return (add_dev(devlistp, name, flags, description, errbuf));
1038}
1039
1040/*
1041 * Look for a given device in the specified list of devices, and return
1042 * the entry for it if we find it or NULL if we don't.
1043 */
1044pcap_if_t *
1045find_dev(pcap_if_list_t *devlistp, const char *name)
1046{
1047 pcap_if_t *curdev;
1048
1049 /*
1050 * Is there an entry in the list for this device?
1051 */
1052 for (curdev = devlistp->beginning; curdev != NULL;
1053 curdev = curdev->next) {
1054 if (strcmp(name, curdev->name) == 0) {
1055 /*
1056 * We found it, so, yes, there is. No need to
1057 * add it. Provide the entry we found to our
1058 * caller.
1059 */
1060 return (curdev);
1061 }
1062 }
1063
1064 /*
1065 * No.
1066 */
1067 return (NULL);
1068}
1069
1070/*
1071 * Attempt to add an entry for a device, with the specified flags
1072 * and description, and, if that succeeds, return 0 and return a pointer
1073 * to the new entry, otherwise return NULL and set errbuf to an error
1074 * message.
1075 *
1076 * If we weren't given a description, try to get one.
1077 */
1078pcap_if_t *
1079add_dev(pcap_if_list_t *devlistp, const char *name, bpf_u_int32 flags,
1080 const char *description, char *errbuf)
1081{
1082 pcap_if_t *curdev, *prevdev, *nextdev;
1083 u_int this_figure_of_merit, nextdev_figure_of_merit;
1084
1085 curdev = malloc(sizeof(pcap_if_t));
1086 if (curdev == NULL) {
1087 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1088 errno, "malloc");
1089 return (NULL);
1090 }
1091
1092 /*
1093 * Fill in the entry.
1094 */
1095 curdev->next = NULL;
1096 curdev->name = strdup(name);
1097 if (curdev->name == NULL) {
1098 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1099 errno, "malloc");
1100 free(curdev);
1101 return (NULL);
1102 }
1103 if (description == NULL) {
1104 /*
1105 * We weren't handed a description for the interface.
1106 */
1107 curdev->description = NULL;
1108 } else {
1109 /*
1110 * We were handed a description; make a copy.
1111 */
1112 curdev->description = strdup(description);
1113 if (curdev->description == NULL) {
1114 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1115 errno, "malloc");
1116 free(curdev->name);
1117 free(curdev);
1118 return (NULL);
1119 }
1120 }
1121 curdev->addresses = NULL; /* list starts out as empty */
1122 curdev->flags = flags;
1123
1124 /*
1125 * Add it to the list, in the appropriate location.
1126 * First, get the "figure of merit" for this interface.
1127 */
1128 this_figure_of_merit = get_figure_of_merit(curdev);
1129
1130 /*
1131 * Now look for the last interface with an figure of merit
1132 * less than or equal to the new interface's figure of merit.
1133 *
1134 * We start with "prevdev" being NULL, meaning we're before
1135 * the first element in the list.
1136 */
1137 prevdev = NULL;
1138 for (;;) {
1139 /*
1140 * Get the interface after this one.
1141 */
1142 if (prevdev == NULL) {
1143 /*
1144 * The next element is the first element.
1145 */
1146 nextdev = devlistp->beginning;
1147 } else
1148 nextdev = prevdev->next;
1149
1150 /*
1151 * Are we at the end of the list?
1152 */
1153 if (nextdev == NULL) {
1154 /*
1155 * Yes - we have to put the new entry after "prevdev".
1156 */
1157 break;
1158 }
1159
1160 /*
1161 * Is the new interface's figure of merit less
1162 * than the next interface's figure of merit,
1163 * meaning that the new interface is better
1164 * than the next interface?
1165 */
1166 nextdev_figure_of_merit = get_figure_of_merit(nextdev);
1167 if (this_figure_of_merit < nextdev_figure_of_merit) {
1168 /*
1169 * Yes - we should put the new entry
1170 * before "nextdev", i.e. after "prevdev".
1171 */
1172 break;
1173 }
1174
1175 prevdev = nextdev;
1176 }
1177
1178 /*
1179 * Insert before "nextdev".
1180 */
1181 curdev->next = nextdev;
1182
1183 /*
1184 * Insert after "prevdev" - unless "prevdev" is null,
1185 * in which case this is the first interface.
1186 */
1187 if (prevdev == NULL) {
1188 /*
1189 * This is the first interface. Make it
1190 * the first element in the list of devices.
1191 */
1192 devlistp->beginning = curdev;
1193 } else
1194 prevdev->next = curdev;
1195 return (curdev);
1196}
1197
1198/*
1199 * Free a list of interfaces.
1200 */
1201void
1202pcap_freealldevs(pcap_if_t *alldevs)
1203{
1204 pcap_if_t *curdev, *nextdev;
1205 pcap_addr_t *curaddr, *nextaddr;
1206
1207 for (curdev = alldevs; curdev != NULL; curdev = nextdev) {
1208 nextdev = curdev->next;
1209
1210 /*
1211 * Free all addresses.
1212 */
1213 for (curaddr = curdev->addresses; curaddr != NULL; curaddr = nextaddr) {
1214 nextaddr = curaddr->next;
1215 if (curaddr->addr)
1216 free(curaddr->addr);
1217 if (curaddr->netmask)
1218 free(curaddr->netmask);
1219 if (curaddr->broadaddr)
1220 free(curaddr->broadaddr);
1221 if (curaddr->dstaddr)
1222 free(curaddr->dstaddr);
1223 free(curaddr);
1224 }
1225
1226 /*
1227 * Free the name string.
1228 */
1229 free(curdev->name);
1230
1231 /*
1232 * Free the description string, if any.
1233 */
1234 if (curdev->description != NULL)
1235 free(curdev->description);
1236
1237 /*
1238 * Free the interface.
1239 */
1240 free(curdev);
1241 }
1242}
1243
1244/*
1245 * pcap-npf.c has its own pcap_lookupdev(), for compatibility reasons, as
1246 * it actually returns the names of all interfaces, with a NUL separator
1247 * between them; some callers may depend on that.
1248 *
1249 * MS-DOS has its own pcap_lookupdev(), but that might be useful only
1250 * as an optimization.
1251 *
1252 * In all other cases, we just use pcap_findalldevs() to get a list of
1253 * devices, and pick from that list.
1254 */
1255#if !defined(HAVE_PACKET32) && !defined(MSDOS)
1256/*
1257 * Return the name of a network interface attached to the system, or NULL
1258 * if none can be found. The interface must be configured up; the
1259 * lowest unit number is preferred; loopback is ignored.
1260 */
1261char *
1262pcap_lookupdev(char *errbuf)
1263{
1264 pcap_if_t *alldevs;
1265#ifdef _WIN32
1266 /*
1267 * Windows - use the same size as the old WinPcap 3.1 code.
1268 * XXX - this is probably bigger than it needs to be.
1269 */
1270 #define IF_NAMESIZE 8192
1271#else
1272 /*
1273 * UN*X - use the system's interface name size.
1274 * XXX - that might not be large enough for capture devices
1275 * that aren't regular network interfaces.
1276 */
1277 /* for old BSD systems, including bsdi3 */
1278 #ifndef IF_NAMESIZE
1279 #define IF_NAMESIZE IFNAMSIZ
1280 #endif
1281#endif
1282 static char device[IF_NAMESIZE + 1];
1283 char *ret;
1284
1285 if (pcap_findalldevs(&alldevs, errbuf) == -1)
1286 return (NULL);
1287
1288 if (alldevs == NULL || (alldevs->flags & PCAP_IF_LOOPBACK)) {
1289 /*
1290 * There are no devices on the list, or the first device
1291 * on the list is a loopback device, which means there
1292 * are no non-loopback devices on the list. This means
1293 * we can't return any device.
1294 *
1295 * XXX - why not return a loopback device? If we can't
1296 * capture on it, it won't be on the list, and if it's
1297 * on the list, there aren't any non-loopback devices,
1298 * so why not just supply it as the default device?
1299 */
1300 (void)strlcpy(errbuf, "no suitable device found",
1301 PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE);
1302 ret = NULL;
1303 } else {
1304 /*
1305 * Return the name of the first device on the list.
1306 */
1307 (void)strlcpy(device, alldevs->name, sizeof(device));
1308 ret = device;
1309 }
1310
1311 pcap_freealldevs(alldevs);
1312 return (ret);
1313}
1314#endif /* !defined(HAVE_PACKET32) && !defined(MSDOS) */
1315
1316#if !defined(_WIN32) && !defined(MSDOS)
1317/*
1318 * We don't just fetch the entire list of devices, search for the
1319 * particular device, and use its first IPv4 address, as that's too
1320 * much work to get just one device's netmask.
1321 *
1322 * If we had an API to get attributes for a given device, we could
1323 * use that.
1324 */
1325int
1326pcap_lookupnet(const char *device, bpf_u_int32 *netp, bpf_u_int32 *maskp,
1327 char *errbuf)
1328{
1329 register int fd;
1330 register struct sockaddr_in *sin4;
1331 struct ifreq ifr;
1332
1333 /*
1334 * The pseudo-device "any" listens on all interfaces and therefore
1335 * has the network address and -mask "0.0.0.0" therefore catching
1336 * all traffic. Using NULL for the interface is the same as "any".
1337 */
1338 if (!device || strcmp(device, "any") == 0
1339#ifdef HAVE_DAG_API
1340 || strstr(device, "dag") != NULL
1341#endif
1342#ifdef HAVE_SEPTEL_API
1343 || strstr(device, "septel") != NULL
1344#endif
1345#ifdef PCAP_SUPPORT_BT
1346 || strstr(device, "bluetooth") != NULL
1347#endif
1348#ifdef PCAP_SUPPORT_USB
1349 || strstr(device, "usbmon") != NULL
1350#endif
1351#ifdef HAVE_SNF_API
1352 || strstr(device, "snf") != NULL
1353#endif
1354#ifdef PCAP_SUPPORT_NETMAP
1355 || strncmp(device, "netmap:", 7) == 0
1356 || strncmp(device, "vale", 4) == 0
1357#endif
1358 ) {
1359 *netp = *maskp = 0;
1360 return 0;
1361 }
1362
1363 fd = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_DGRAM, 0);
1364 if (fd < 0) {
1365 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1366 errno, "socket");
1367 return (-1);
1368 }
1369 memset(&ifr, 0, sizeof(ifr));
1370#ifdef linux
1371 /* XXX Work around Linux kernel bug */
1372 ifr.ifr_addr.sa_family = AF_INET;
1373#endif
1374 (void)strlcpy(ifr.ifr_name, device, sizeof(ifr.ifr_name));
1375 if (ioctl(fd, SIOCGIFADDR, (char *)&ifr) < 0) {
1376 if (errno == EADDRNOTAVAIL) {
1377 (void)pcap_snprintf(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1378 "%s: no IPv4 address assigned", device);
1379 } else {
1380 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1381 errno, "SIOCGIFADDR: %s", device);
1382 }
1383 (void)close(fd);
1384 return (-1);
1385 }
1386 sin4 = (struct sockaddr_in *)&ifr.ifr_addr;
1387 *netp = sin4->sin_addr.s_addr;
1388 memset(&ifr, 0, sizeof(ifr));
1389#ifdef linux
1390 /* XXX Work around Linux kernel bug */
1391 ifr.ifr_addr.sa_family = AF_INET;
1392#endif
1393 (void)strlcpy(ifr.ifr_name, device, sizeof(ifr.ifr_name));
1394 if (ioctl(fd, SIOCGIFNETMASK, (char *)&ifr) < 0) {
1395 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1396 errno, "SIOCGIFNETMASK: %s", device);
1397 (void)close(fd);
1398 return (-1);
1399 }
1400 (void)close(fd);
1401 *maskp = sin4->sin_addr.s_addr;
1402 if (*maskp == 0) {
1403 if (IN_CLASSA(*netp))
1404 *maskp = IN_CLASSA_NET;
1405 else if (IN_CLASSB(*netp))
1406 *maskp = IN_CLASSB_NET;
1407 else if (IN_CLASSC(*netp))
1408 *maskp = IN_CLASSC_NET;
1409 else {
1410 (void)pcap_snprintf(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1411 "inet class for 0x%x unknown", *netp);
1412 return (-1);
1413 }
1414 }
1415 *netp &= *maskp;
1416 return (0);
1417}
1418#endif /* !defined(_WIN32) && !defined(MSDOS) */
1419
1420#ifdef ENABLE_REMOTE
1421#include "pcap-rpcap.h"
1422
1423/*
1424 * Extract a substring from a string.
1425 */
1426static char *
1427get_substring(const char *p, size_t len, char *ebuf)
1428{
1429 char *token;
1430
1431 token = malloc(len + 1);
1432 if (token == NULL) {
1433 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(ebuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1434 errno, "malloc");
1435 return (NULL);
1436 }
1437 memcpy(token, p, len);
1438 token[len] = '\0';
1439 return (token);
1440}
1441
1442/*
1443 * Parse a capture source that might be a URL.
1444 *
1445 * If the source is not a URL, *schemep, *userinfop, *hostp, and *portp
1446 * are set to NULL, *pathp is set to point to the source, and 0 is
1447 * returned.
1448 *
1449 * If source is a URL, and the URL refers to a local device (a special
1450 * case of rpcap:), *schemep, *userinfop, *hostp, and *portp are set
1451 * to NULL, *pathp is set to point to the device name, and 0 is returned.
1452 *
1453 * If source is a URL, and it's not a special case that refers to a local
1454 * device, and the parse succeeds:
1455 *
1456 * *schemep is set to point to an allocated string containing the scheme;
1457 *
1458 * if user information is present in the URL, *userinfop is set to point
1459 * to an allocated string containing the user information, otherwise
1460 * it's set to NULL;
1461 *
1462 * if host information is present in the URL, *hostp is set to point
1463 * to an allocated string containing the host information, otherwise
1464 * it's set to NULL;
1465 *
1466 * if a port number is present in the URL, *portp is set to point
1467 * to an allocated string containing the port number, otherwise
1468 * it's set to NULL;
1469 *
1470 * *pathp is set to point to an allocated string containing the
1471 * path;
1472 *
1473 * and 0 is returned.
1474 *
1475 * If the parse fails, ebuf is set to an error string, and -1 is returned.
1476 */
1477static int
1478pcap_parse_source(const char *source, char **schemep, char **userinfop,
1479 char **hostp, char **portp, char **pathp, char *ebuf)
1480{
1481 char *colonp;
1482 size_t scheme_len;
1483 char *scheme;
1484 const char *endp;
1485 size_t authority_len;
1486 char *authority;
1487 char *parsep, *atsignp, *bracketp;
1488 char *userinfo, *host, *port, *path;
1489
1490 /*
1491 * Start out returning nothing.
1492 */
1493 *schemep = NULL;
1494 *userinfop = NULL;
1495 *hostp = NULL;
1496 *portp = NULL;
1497 *pathp = NULL;
1498
1499 /*
1500 * RFC 3986 says:
1501 *
1502 * URI = scheme ":" hier-part [ "?" query ] [ "#" fragment ]
1503 *
1504 * hier-part = "//" authority path-abempty
1505 * / path-absolute
1506 * / path-rootless
1507 * / path-empty
1508 *
1509 * authority = [ userinfo "@" ] host [ ":" port ]
1510 *
1511 * userinfo = *( unreserved / pct-encoded / sub-delims / ":" )
1512 *
1513 * Step 1: look for the ":" at the end of the scheme.
1514 * A colon in the source is *NOT* sufficient to indicate that
1515 * this is a URL, as interface names on some platforms might
1516 * include colons (e.g., I think some Solaris interfaces
1517 * might).
1518 */
1519 colonp = strchr(source, ':');
1520 if (colonp == NULL) {
1521 /*
1522 * The source is the device to open.
1523 * Return a NULL pointer for the scheme, user information,
1524 * host, and port, and return the device as the path.
1525 */
1526 *pathp = strdup(source);
1527 if (*pathp == NULL) {
1528 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(ebuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1529 errno, "malloc");
1530 return (-1);
1531 }
1532 return (0);
1533 }
1534
1535 /*
1536 * All schemes must have "//" after them, i.e. we only support
1537 * hier-part = "//" authority path-abempty, not
1538 * hier-part = path-absolute
1539 * hier-part = path-rootless
1540 * hier-part = path-empty
1541 *
1542 * We need that in order to distinguish between a local device
1543 * name that happens to contain a colon and a URI.
1544 */
1545 if (strncmp(colonp + 1, "//", 2) != 0) {
1546 /*
1547 * The source is the device to open.
1548 * Return a NULL pointer for the scheme, user information,
1549 * host, and port, and return the device as the path.
1550 */
1551 *pathp = strdup(source);
1552 if (*pathp == NULL) {
1553 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(ebuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1554 errno, "malloc");
1555 return (-1);
1556 }
1557 return (0);
1558 }
1559
1560 /*
1561 * XXX - check whether the purported scheme could be a scheme?
1562 */
1563
1564 /*
1565 * OK, this looks like a URL.
1566 * Get the scheme.
1567 */
1568 scheme_len = colonp - source;
1569 scheme = malloc(scheme_len + 1);
1570 if (scheme == NULL) {
1571 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(ebuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1572 errno, "malloc");
1573 return (-1);
1574 }
1575 memcpy(scheme, source, scheme_len);
1576 scheme[scheme_len] = '\0';
1577
1578 /*
1579 * Treat file: specially - take everything after file:// as
1580 * the pathname.
1581 */
1582 if (pcap_strcasecmp(scheme, "file") == 0) {
1583 *schemep = scheme;
1584 *pathp = strdup(colonp + 3);
1585 if (*pathp == NULL) {
1586 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(ebuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1587 errno, "malloc");
1588 return (-1);
1589 }
1590 return (0);
1591 }
1592
1593 /*
1594 * The WinPcap documentation says you can specify a local
1595 * interface with "rpcap://{device}"; we special-case
1596 * that here. If the scheme is "rpcap", and there are
1597 * no slashes past the "//", we just return the device.
1598 *
1599 * XXX - %-escaping?
1600 */
1601 if (pcap_strcasecmp(scheme, "rpcap") == 0 &&
1602 strchr(colonp + 3, '/') == NULL) {
1603 /*
1604 * Local device.
1605 *
1606 * Return a NULL pointer for the scheme, user information,
1607 * host, and port, and return the device as the path.
1608 */
1609 free(scheme);
1610 *pathp = strdup(colonp + 3);
1611 if (*pathp == NULL) {
1612 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(ebuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1613 errno, "malloc");
1614 return (-1);
1615 }
1616 return (0);
1617 }
1618
1619 /*
1620 * OK, now start parsing the authority.
1621 * Get token, terminated with / or terminated at the end of
1622 * the string.
1623 */
1624 authority_len = strcspn(colonp + 3, "/");
1625 authority = get_substring(colonp + 3, authority_len, ebuf);
1626 if (authority == NULL) {
1627 /*
1628 * Error.
1629 */
1630 free(scheme);
1631 return (-1);
1632 }
1633 endp = colonp + 3 + authority_len;
1634
1635 /*
1636 * Now carve the authority field into its components.
1637 */
1638 parsep = authority;
1639
1640 /*
1641 * Is there a userinfo field?
1642 */
1643 atsignp = strchr(parsep, '@');
1644 if (atsignp != NULL) {
1645 /*
1646 * Yes.
1647 */
1648 size_t userinfo_len;
1649
1650 userinfo_len = atsignp - parsep;
1651 userinfo = get_substring(parsep, userinfo_len, ebuf);
1652 if (userinfo == NULL) {
1653 /*
1654 * Error.
1655 */
1656 free(authority);
1657 free(scheme);
1658 return (-1);
1659 }
1660 parsep = atsignp + 1;
1661 } else {
1662 /*
1663 * No.
1664 */
1665 userinfo = NULL;
1666 }
1667
1668 /*
1669 * Is there a host field?
1670 */
1671 if (*parsep == '\0') {
1672 /*
1673 * No; there's no host field or port field.
1674 */
1675 host = NULL;
1676 port = NULL;
1677 } else {
1678 /*
1679 * Yes.
1680 */
1681 size_t host_len;
1682
1683 /*
1684 * Is it an IP-literal?
1685 */
1686 if (*parsep == '[') {
1687 /*
1688 * Yes.
1689 * Treat verything up to the closing square
1690 * bracket as the IP-Literal; we don't worry
1691 * about whether it's a valid IPv6address or
1692 * IPvFuture.
1693 */
1694 bracketp = strchr(parsep, ']');
1695 if (bracketp == NULL) {
1696 /*
1697 * There's no closing square bracket.
1698 */
1699 pcap_snprintf(ebuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1700 "IP-literal in URL doesn't end with ]");
1701 free(userinfo);
1702 free(authority);
1703 free(scheme);
1704 return (-1);
1705 }
1706 if (*(bracketp + 1) != '\0' &&
1707 *(bracketp + 1) != ':') {
1708 /*
1709 * There's extra crud after the
1710 * closing square bracketn.
1711 */
1712 pcap_snprintf(ebuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1713 "Extra text after IP-literal in URL");
1714 free(userinfo);
1715 free(authority);
1716 free(scheme);
1717 return (-1);
1718 }
1719 host_len = (bracketp - 1) - parsep;
1720 host = get_substring(parsep + 1, host_len, ebuf);
1721 if (host == NULL) {
1722 /*
1723 * Error.
1724 */
1725 free(userinfo);
1726 free(authority);
1727 free(scheme);
1728 return (-1);
1729 }
1730 parsep = bracketp + 1;
1731 } else {
1732 /*
1733 * No.
1734 * Treat everything up to a : or the end of
1735 * the string as the host.
1736 */
1737 host_len = strcspn(parsep, ":");
1738 host = get_substring(parsep, host_len, ebuf);
1739 if (host == NULL) {
1740 /*
1741 * Error.
1742 */
1743 free(userinfo);
1744 free(authority);
1745 free(scheme);
1746 return (-1);
1747 }
1748 parsep = parsep + host_len;
1749 }
1750
1751 /*
1752 * Is there a port field?
1753 */
1754 if (*parsep == ':') {
1755 /*
1756 * Yes. It's the rest of the authority field.
1757 */
1758 size_t port_len;
1759
1760 parsep++;
1761 port_len = strlen(parsep);
1762 port = get_substring(parsep, port_len, ebuf);
1763 if (port == NULL) {
1764 /*
1765 * Error.
1766 */
1767 free(host);
1768 free(userinfo);
1769 free(authority);
1770 free(scheme);
1771 return (-1);
1772 }
1773 } else {
1774 /*
1775 * No.
1776 */
1777 port = NULL;
1778 }
1779 }
1780 free(authority);
1781
1782 /*
1783 * Everything else is the path. Strip off the leading /.
1784 */
1785 if (*endp == '\0')
1786 path = strdup("");
1787 else
1788 path = strdup(endp + 1);
1789 if (path == NULL) {
1790 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(ebuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1791 errno, "malloc");
1792 free(port);
1793 free(host);
1794 free(userinfo);
1795 free(scheme);
1796 return (-1);
1797 }
1798 *schemep = scheme;
1799 *userinfop = userinfo;
1800 *hostp = host;
1801 *portp = port;
1802 *pathp = path;
1803 return (0);
1804}
1805
1806int
1807pcap_createsrcstr(char *source, int type, const char *host, const char *port,
1808 const char *name, char *errbuf)
1809{
1810 switch (type) {
1811
1812 case PCAP_SRC_FILE:
1813 strlcpy(source, PCAP_SRC_FILE_STRING, PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1814 if (name != NULL && *name != '\0') {
1815 strlcat(source, name, PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1816 return (0);
1817 } else {
1818 pcap_snprintf(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1819 "The file name cannot be NULL.");
1820 return (-1);
1821 }
1822
1823 case PCAP_SRC_IFREMOTE:
1824 strlcpy(source, PCAP_SRC_IF_STRING, PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1825 if (host != NULL && *host != '\0') {
1826 if (strchr(host, ':') != NULL) {
1827 /*
1828 * The host name contains a colon, so it's
1829 * probably an IPv6 address, and needs to
1830 * be included in square brackets.
1831 */
1832 strlcat(source, "[", PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1833 strlcat(source, host, PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1834 strlcat(source, "]", PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1835 } else
1836 strlcat(source, host, PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1837
1838 if (port != NULL && *port != '\0') {
1839 strlcat(source, ":", PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1840 strlcat(source, port, PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1841 }
1842
1843 strlcat(source, "/", PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1844 } else {
1845 pcap_snprintf(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1846 "The host name cannot be NULL.");
1847 return (-1);
1848 }
1849
1850 if (name != NULL && *name != '\0')
1851 strlcat(source, name, PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1852
1853 return (0);
1854
1855 case PCAP_SRC_IFLOCAL:
1856 strlcpy(source, PCAP_SRC_IF_STRING, PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1857
1858 if (name != NULL && *name != '\0')
1859 strlcat(source, name, PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1860
1861 return (0);
1862
1863 default:
1864 pcap_snprintf(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
1865 "The interface type is not valid.");
1866 return (-1);
1867 }
1868}
1869
1870int
1871pcap_parsesrcstr(const char *source, int *type, char *host, char *port,
1872 char *name, char *errbuf)
1873{
1874 char *scheme, *tmpuserinfo, *tmphost, *tmpport, *tmppath;
1875
1876 /* Initialization stuff */
1877 if (host)
1878 *host = '\0';
1879 if (port)
1880 *port = '\0';
1881 if (name)
1882 *name = '\0';
1883
1884 /* Parse the source string */
1885 if (pcap_parse_source(source, &scheme, &tmpuserinfo, &tmphost,
1886 &tmpport, &tmppath, errbuf) == -1) {
1887 /*
1888 * Fail.
1889 */
1890 return (-1);
1891 }
1892
1893 if (scheme == NULL) {
1894 /*
1895 * Local device.
1896 */
1897 if (name && tmppath)
1898 strlcpy(name, tmppath, PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1899 if (type)
1900 *type = PCAP_SRC_IFLOCAL;
1901 free(tmppath);
1902 free(tmpport);
1903 free(tmphost);
1904 free(tmpuserinfo);
1905 return (0);
1906 }
1907
1908 if (strcmp(scheme, "rpcap") == 0) {
1909 /*
1910 * rpcap://
1911 *
1912 * pcap_parse_source() has already handled the case of
1913 * rpcap://device
1914 */
1915 if (host && tmphost) {
1916 if (tmpuserinfo)
1917 pcap_snprintf(host, PCAP_BUF_SIZE, "%s@%s",
1918 tmpuserinfo, tmphost);
1919 else
1920 strlcpy(host, tmphost, PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1921 }
1922 if (port && tmpport)
1923 strlcpy(port, tmpport, PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1924 if (name && tmppath)
1925 strlcpy(name, tmppath, PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1926 if (type)
1927 *type = PCAP_SRC_IFREMOTE;
1928 free(tmppath);
1929 free(tmpport);
1930 free(tmphost);
1931 free(tmpuserinfo);
1932 free(scheme);
1933 return (0);
1934 }
1935
1936 if (strcmp(scheme, "file") == 0) {
1937 /*
1938 * file://
1939 */
1940 if (name && tmppath)
1941 strlcpy(name, tmppath, PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1942 if (type)
1943 *type = PCAP_SRC_FILE;
1944 free(tmppath);
1945 free(tmpport);
1946 free(tmphost);
1947 free(tmpuserinfo);
1948 free(scheme);
1949 return (0);
1950 }
1951
1952 /*
1953 * Neither rpcap: nor file:; just treat the entire string
1954 * as a local device.
1955 */
1956 if (name)
1957 strlcpy(name, source, PCAP_BUF_SIZE);
1958 if (type)
1959 *type = PCAP_SRC_IFLOCAL;
1960 free(tmppath);
1961 free(tmpport);
1962 free(tmphost);
1963 free(tmpuserinfo);
1964 free(scheme);
1965 return (0);
1966}
1967#endif
1968
1969pcap_t *
1970pcap_create(const char *device, char *errbuf)
1971{
1972 size_t i;
1973 int is_theirs;
1974 pcap_t *p;
1975 char *device_str;
1976
1977 /*
1978 * A null device name is equivalent to the "any" device -
1979 * which might not be supported on this platform, but
1980 * this means that you'll get a "not supported" error
1981 * rather than, say, a crash when we try to dereference
1982 * the null pointer.
1983 */
1984 if (device == NULL)
1985 device_str = strdup("any");
1986 else {
1987#ifdef _WIN32
1988 /*
1989 * If the string appears to be little-endian UCS-2/UTF-16,
1990 * convert it to ASCII.
1991 *
1992 * XXX - to UTF-8 instead? Or report an error if any
1993 * character isn't ASCII?
1994 */
1995 if (device[0] != '\0' && device[1] == '\0') {
1996 size_t length;
1997
1998 length = wcslen((wchar_t *)device);
1999 device_str = (char *)malloc(length + 1);
2000 if (device_str == NULL) {
2001 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(errbuf,
2002 PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE, errno,
2003 "malloc");
2004 return (NULL);
2005 }
2006
2007 pcap_snprintf(device_str, length + 1, "%ws",
2008 (const wchar_t *)device);
2009 } else
2010#endif
2011 device_str = strdup(device);
2012 }
2013 if (device_str == NULL) {
2014 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
2015 errno, "malloc");
2016 return (NULL);
2017 }
2018
2019 /*
2020 * Try each of the non-local-network-interface capture
2021 * source types until we find one that works for this
2022 * device or run out of types.
2023 */
2024 for (i = 0; capture_source_types[i].create_op != NULL; i++) {
2025 is_theirs = 0;
2026 p = capture_source_types[i].create_op(device_str, errbuf,
2027 &is_theirs);
2028 if (is_theirs) {
2029 /*
2030 * The device name refers to a device of the
2031 * type in question; either it succeeded,
2032 * in which case p refers to a pcap_t to
2033 * later activate for the device, or it
2034 * failed, in which case p is null and we
2035 * should return that to report the failure
2036 * to create.
2037 */
2038 if (p == NULL) {
2039 /*
2040 * We assume the caller filled in errbuf.
2041 */
2042 free(device_str);
2043 return (NULL);
2044 }
2045 p->opt.device = device_str;
2046 return (p);
2047 }
2048 }
2049
2050 /*
2051 * OK, try it as a regular network interface.
2052 */
2053 p = pcap_create_interface(device_str, errbuf);
2054 if (p == NULL) {
2055 /*
2056 * We assume the caller filled in errbuf.
2057 */
2058 free(device_str);
2059 return (NULL);
2060 }
2061 p->opt.device = device_str;
2062 return (p);
2063}
2064
2065/*
2066 * Set nonblocking mode on an unactivated pcap_t; this sets a flag
2067 * checked by pcap_activate(), which sets the mode after calling
2068 * the activate routine.
2069 */
2070static int
2071pcap_setnonblock_unactivated(pcap_t *p, int nonblock)
2072{
2073 p->opt.nonblock = nonblock;
2074 return (0);
2075}
2076
2077static void
2078initialize_ops(pcap_t *p)
2079{
2080 /*
2081 * Set operation pointers for operations that only work on
2082 * an activated pcap_t to point to a routine that returns
2083 * a "this isn't activated" error.
2084 */
2085 p->read_op = (read_op_t)pcap_not_initialized;
2086 p->inject_op = (inject_op_t)pcap_not_initialized;
2087 p->setfilter_op = (setfilter_op_t)pcap_not_initialized;
2088 p->setdirection_op = (setdirection_op_t)pcap_not_initialized;
2089 p->set_datalink_op = (set_datalink_op_t)pcap_not_initialized;
2090 p->getnonblock_op = (getnonblock_op_t)pcap_not_initialized;
2091 p->stats_op = (stats_op_t)pcap_not_initialized;
2092#ifdef _WIN32
2093 p->stats_ex_op = (stats_ex_op_t)pcap_not_initialized_ptr;
2094 p->setbuff_op = (setbuff_op_t)pcap_not_initialized;
2095 p->setmode_op = (setmode_op_t)pcap_not_initialized;
2096 p->setmintocopy_op = (setmintocopy_op_t)pcap_not_initialized;
2097 p->getevent_op = pcap_getevent_not_initialized;
2098 p->oid_get_request_op = (oid_get_request_op_t)pcap_not_initialized;
2099 p->oid_set_request_op = (oid_set_request_op_t)pcap_not_initialized;
2100 p->sendqueue_transmit_op = pcap_sendqueue_transmit_not_initialized;
2101 p->setuserbuffer_op = (setuserbuffer_op_t)pcap_not_initialized;
2102 p->live_dump_op = (live_dump_op_t)pcap_not_initialized;
2103 p->live_dump_ended_op = (live_dump_ended_op_t)pcap_not_initialized;
2104 p->get_airpcap_handle_op = pcap_get_airpcap_handle_not_initialized;
2105#endif
2106
2107 /*
2108 * Default cleanup operation - implementations can override
2109 * this, but should call pcap_cleanup_live_common() after
2110 * doing their own additional cleanup.
2111 */
2112 p->cleanup_op = pcap_cleanup_live_common;
2113
2114 /*
2115 * In most cases, the standard one-shot callback can
2116 * be used for pcap_next()/pcap_next_ex().
2117 */
2118 p->oneshot_callback = pcap_oneshot;
2119}
2120
2121static pcap_t *
2122pcap_alloc_pcap_t(char *ebuf, size_t size)
2123{
2124 char *chunk;
2125 pcap_t *p;
2126
2127 /*
2128 * Allocate a chunk of memory big enough for a pcap_t
2129 * plus a structure following it of size "size". The
2130 * structure following it is a private data structure
2131 * for the routines that handle this pcap_t.
2132 *
2133 * The structure following it must be aligned on
2134 * the appropriate alignment boundary for this platform.
2135 * We align on an 8-byte boundary as that's probably what
2136 * at least some platforms do, even with 32-bit integers,
2137 * and because we can't be sure that some values won't
2138 * require 8-byte alignment even on platforms with 32-bit
2139 * integers.
2140 */
2141#define PCAP_T_ALIGNED_SIZE ((sizeof(pcap_t) + 7) & ~0x7)
2142 chunk = malloc(PCAP_T_ALIGNED_SIZE + size);
2143 if (chunk == NULL) {
2144 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(ebuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE,
2145 errno, "malloc");
2146 return (NULL);
2147 }
2148 memset(chunk, 0, PCAP_T_ALIGNED_SIZE + size);
2149
2150 /*
2151 * Get a pointer to the pcap_t at the beginning.
2152 */
2153 p = (pcap_t *)chunk;
2154
2155#ifdef _WIN32
2156 p->handle = INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE; /* not opened yet */
2157#else /* _WIN32 */
2158 p->fd = -1; /* not opened yet */
2159#ifndef MSDOS
2160 p->selectable_fd = -1;
2161 p->required_select_timeout = NULL;
2162#endif /* MSDOS */
2163#endif /* _WIN32 */
2164
2165 if (size == 0) {
2166 /* No private data was requested. */
2167 p->priv = NULL;
2168 } else {
2169 /*
2170 * Set the pointer to the private data; that's the structure
2171 * of size "size" following the pcap_t.
2172 */
2173 p->priv = (void *)(chunk + PCAP_T_ALIGNED_SIZE);
2174 }
2175
2176 return (p);
2177}
2178
2179pcap_t *
2180pcap_create_common(char *ebuf, size_t size)
2181{
2182 pcap_t *p;
2183
2184 p = pcap_alloc_pcap_t(ebuf, size);
2185 if (p == NULL)
2186 return (NULL);
2187
2188 /*
2189 * Default to "can't set rfmon mode"; if it's supported by
2190 * a platform, the create routine that called us can set
2191 * the op to its routine to check whether a particular
2192 * device supports it.
2193 */
2194 p->can_set_rfmon_op = pcap_cant_set_rfmon;
2195
2196 /*
2197 * If pcap_setnonblock() is called on a not-yet-activated
2198 * pcap_t, default to setting a flag and turning
2199 * on non-blocking mode when activated.
2200 */
2201 p->setnonblock_op = pcap_setnonblock_unactivated;
2202
2203 initialize_ops(p);
2204
2205 /* put in some defaults*/
2206 p->snapshot = 0; /* max packet size unspecified */
2207 p->opt.timeout = 0; /* no timeout specified */
2208 p->opt.buffer_size = 0; /* use the platform's default */
2209 p->opt.promisc = 0;
2210 p->opt.rfmon = 0;
2211 p->opt.immediate = 0;
2212 p->opt.tstamp_type = -1; /* default to not setting time stamp type */
2213 p->opt.tstamp_precision = PCAP_TSTAMP_PRECISION_MICRO;
2214 /*
2215 * Platform-dependent options.
2216 */
2217#ifdef __linux__
2218 p->opt.protocol = 0;
2219#endif
2220#ifdef _WIN32
2221 p->opt.nocapture_local = 0;
2222#endif
2223
2224 /*
2225 * Start out with no BPF code generation flags set.
2226 */
2227 p->bpf_codegen_flags = 0;
2228
2229 return (p);
2230}
2231
2232int
2233pcap_check_activated(pcap_t *p)
2234{
2235 if (p->activated) {
2236 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE, "can't perform "
2237 " operation on activated capture");
2238 return (-1);
2239 }
2240 return (0);
2241}
2242
2243int
2244pcap_set_snaplen(pcap_t *p, int snaplen)
2245{
2246 if (pcap_check_activated(p))
2247 return (PCAP_ERROR_ACTIVATED);
2248 p->snapshot = snaplen;
2249 return (0);
2250}
2251
2252int
2253pcap_set_promisc(pcap_t *p, int promisc)
2254{
2255 if (pcap_check_activated(p))
2256 return (PCAP_ERROR_ACTIVATED);
2257 p->opt.promisc = promisc;
2258 return (0);
2259}
2260

2262pcap_set_rfmon(pcap_t *p, int rfmon)

2264 if (pcap_check_activated(p))
2265 return (PCAP_ERROR_ACTIVATED);
2266 p->opt.rfmon = rfmon;

2270int
2271pcap_set_timeout(pcap_t *p, int timeout_ms)
2272{
2273 if (pcap_check_activated(p))
2274 return (PCAP_ERROR_ACTIVATED);
2275 p->opt.timeout = timeout_ms;
2276 return (0);
2277}
2278
2279int
2280pcap_set_tstamp_type(pcap_t *p, int tstamp_type)
2281{
2282 int i;
2283
2284 if (pcap_check_activated(p))
2285 return (PCAP_ERROR_ACTIVATED);
2286
2287 /*
2288 * The argument should have been u_int, but that's too late
2289 * to change now - it's an API.
2290 */
2291 if (tstamp_type < 0)
2292 return (PCAP_WARNING_TSTAMP_TYPE_NOTSUP);
2293
2294 /*
2295 * If p->tstamp_type_count is 0, we only support PCAP_TSTAMP_HOST;
2296 * the default time stamp type is PCAP_TSTAMP_HOST.
2297 */
2298 if (p->tstamp_type_count == 0) {
2299 if (tstamp_type == PCAP_TSTAMP_HOST) {
2300 p->opt.tstamp_type = tstamp_type;
2301 return (0);
2302 }
2303 } else {
2304 /*
2305 * Check whether we claim to support this type of time stamp.
2306 */
2307 for (i = 0; i < p->tstamp_type_count; i++) {
2308 if (p->tstamp_type_list[i] == (u_int)tstamp_type) {
2309 /*
2310 * Yes.
2311 */
2312 p->opt.tstamp_type = tstamp_type;
2313 return (0);
2314 }
2315 }
2316 }
2317
2318 /*
2319 * We don't support this type of time stamp.
2320 */
2321 return (PCAP_WARNING_TSTAMP_TYPE_NOTSUP);
2322}
2323
2324int
2325pcap_set_immediate_mode(pcap_t *p, int immediate)
2326{
2327 if (pcap_check_activated(p))
2328 return (PCAP_ERROR_ACTIVATED);
2329 p->opt.immediate = immediate;
2330 return (0);
2331}
2332
2333int
2334pcap_set_buffer_size(pcap_t *p, int buffer_size)
2335{
2336 if (pcap_check_activated(p))
2337 return (PCAP_ERROR_ACTIVATED);
2338 if (buffer_size <= 0) {
2339 /*
2340 * Silently ignore invalid values.
2341 */
2342 return (0);
2343 }
2344 p->opt.buffer_size = buffer_size;
2345 return (0);
2346}
2347
2348int
2349pcap_set_tstamp_precision(pcap_t *p, int tstamp_precision)
2350{
2351 int i;
2352
2353 if (pcap_check_activated(p))
2354 return (PCAP_ERROR_ACTIVATED);
2355
2356 /*
2357 * The argument should have been u_int, but that's too late
2358 * to change now - it's an API.
2359 */
2360 if (tstamp_precision < 0)
2361 return (PCAP_ERROR_TSTAMP_PRECISION_NOTSUP);
2362
2363 /*
2364 * If p->tstamp_precision_count is 0, we only support setting
2365 * the time stamp precision to microsecond precision; every
2366 * pcap module *MUST* support microsecond precision, even if
2367 * it does so by converting the native precision to
2368 * microseconds.
2369 */
2370 if (p->tstamp_precision_count == 0) {
2371 if (tstamp_precision == PCAP_TSTAMP_PRECISION_MICRO) {
2372 p->opt.tstamp_precision = tstamp_precision;
2373 return (0);
2374 }
2375 } else {
2376 /*
2377 * Check whether we claim to support this precision of
2378 * time stamp.
2379 */
2380 for (i = 0; i < p->tstamp_precision_count; i++) {
2381 if (p->tstamp_precision_list[i] == (u_int)tstamp_precision) {
2382 /*
2383 * Yes.
2384 */
2385 p->opt.tstamp_precision = tstamp_precision;
2386 return (0);
2387 }
2388 }
2389 }
2390
2391 /*
2392 * We don't support this time stamp precision.
2393 */
2394 return (PCAP_ERROR_TSTAMP_PRECISION_NOTSUP);
2395}
2396
2397int
2398pcap_get_tstamp_precision(pcap_t *p)
2399{
2400 return (p->opt.tstamp_precision);
2401}
2402
2403int
2404pcap_activate(pcap_t *p)
2405{
2406 int status;
2407
2408 /*
2409 * Catch attempts to re-activate an already-activated
2410 * pcap_t; this should, for example, catch code that
2411 * calls pcap_open_live() followed by pcap_activate(),
2412 * as some code that showed up in a Stack Exchange
2413 * question did.
2414 */
2415 if (pcap_check_activated(p))
2416 return (PCAP_ERROR_ACTIVATED);
2417 status = p->activate_op(p);
2418 if (status >= 0) {
2419 /*
2420 * If somebody requested non-blocking mode before
2421 * calling pcap_activate(), turn it on now.
2422 */
2423 if (p->opt.nonblock) {
2424 status = p->setnonblock_op(p, 1);
2425 if (status < 0) {
2426 /*
2427 * Failed. Undo everything done by
2428 * the activate operation.
2429 */
2430 p->cleanup_op(p);
2431 initialize_ops(p);
2432 return (status);
2433 }
2434 }
2435 p->activated = 1;
2436 } else {
2437 if (p->errbuf[0] == '\0') {
2438 /*
2439 * No error message supplied by the activate routine;
2440 * for the benefit of programs that don't specially
2441 * handle errors other than PCAP_ERROR, return the
2442 * error message corresponding to the status.
2443 */
2444 pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE, "%s",
2445 pcap_statustostr(status));
2446 }
2447
2448 /*
2449 * Undo any operation pointer setting, etc. done by
2450 * the activate operation.
2451 */
2452 initialize_ops(p);
2453 }
2454 return (status);
2455}
2456
2457pcap_t *
2458pcap_open_live(const char *device, int snaplen, int promisc, int to_ms, char *errbuf)
2459{
2460 pcap_t *p;
2461 int status;
2462#ifdef ENABLE_REMOTE
2463 char host[PCAP_BUF_SIZE + 1];
2464 char port[PCAP_BUF_SIZE + 1];
2465 char name[PCAP_BUF_SIZE + 1];
2466 int srctype;
2467
2468 /*
2469 * Retrofit - we have to make older applications compatible with
2470 * remote capture.
2471 * So we're calling pcap_open_remote() from here; this is a very
2472 * dirty hack.
2473 * Obviously, we cannot exploit all the new features; for instance,
2474 * we cannot send authentication, we cannot use a UDP data connection,
2475 * and so on.
2476 */
2477 if (pcap_parsesrcstr(device, &srctype, host, port, name, errbuf))
2478 return (NULL);
2479
2480 if (srctype == PCAP_SRC_IFREMOTE) {
2481 /*
2482 * Although we already have host, port and iface, we prefer
2483 * to pass only 'device' to pcap_open_rpcap(), so that it has
2484 * to call pcap_parsesrcstr() again.
2485 * This is less optimized, but much clearer.
2486 */
2487 return (pcap_open_rpcap(device, snaplen,
2488 promisc ? PCAP_OPENFLAG_PROMISCUOUS : 0, to_ms,
2489 NULL, errbuf));
2490 }
2491 if (srctype == PCAP_SRC_FILE) {
2492 pcap_snprintf(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE, "unknown URL scheme \"file\"");
2493 return (NULL);
2494 }
2495 if (srctype == PCAP_SRC_IFLOCAL) {
2496 /*
2497 * If it starts with rpcap://, that refers to a local device
2498 * (no host part in the URL). Remove the rpcap://, and
2499 * fall through to the regular open path.
2500 */
2501 if (strncmp(device, PCAP_SRC_IF_STRING, strlen(PCAP_SRC_IF_STRING)) == 0) {
2502 size_t len = strlen(device) - strlen(PCAP_SRC_IF_STRING) + 1;
2503
2504 if (len > 0)
2505 device += strlen(PCAP_SRC_IF_STRING);
2506 }
2507 }
2508#endif /* ENABLE_REMOTE */
2509
2510 p = pcap_create(device, errbuf);
2511 if (p == NULL)
2512 return (NULL);
2513 status = pcap_set_snaplen(p, snaplen);
2514 if (status < 0)
2515 goto fail;
2516 status = pcap_set_promisc(p, promisc);
2517 if (status < 0)
2518 goto fail;
2519 status = pcap_set_timeout(p, to_ms);
2520 if (status < 0)
2521 goto fail;
2522 /*
2523 * Mark this as opened with pcap_open_live(), so that, for
2524 * example, we show the full list of DLT_ values, rather
2525 * than just the ones that are compatible with capturing
2526 * when not in monitor mode. That allows existing applications
2527 * to work the way they used to work, but allows new applications
2528 * that know about the new open API to, for example, find out the
2529 * DLT_ values that they can select without changing whether
2530 * the adapter is in monitor mode or not.
2531 */
2532 p->oldstyle = 1;
2533 status = pcap_activate(p);
2534 if (status < 0)
2535 goto fail;
2536 return (p);
2537fail:
2538 if (status == PCAP_ERROR)
2539 pcap_snprintf(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE, "%s: %s", device,
2540 p->errbuf);
2541 else if (status == PCAP_ERROR_NO_SUCH_DEVICE ||
2542 status == PCAP_ERROR_PERM_DENIED ||
2543 status == PCAP_ERROR_PROMISC_PERM_DENIED)
2544 pcap_snprintf(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE, "%s: %s (%s)", device,
2545 pcap_statustostr(status), p->errbuf);
2546 else
2547 pcap_snprintf(errbuf, PCAP_ERRBUF_SIZE, "%s: %s", device,
2548 pcap_statustostr(status));
2549 pcap_close(p);
2550 return (NULL);
2551}
2552
2553pcap_t *
2554pcap_open_offline_common(char *ebuf, size_t size)
2555{
2556 pcap_t *p;
2557
2558 p = pcap_alloc_pcap_t(ebuf, size);
2559 if (p == NULL)
2560 return (NULL);
2561
2562 p->opt.tstamp_precision = PCAP_TSTAMP_PRECISION_MICRO;
2563
2564 return (p);
2565}
2566
2567int
2568pcap_dispatch(pcap_t *p, int cnt, pcap_handler callback, u_char *user)
2569{
2570 return (p->read_op(p, cnt, callback, user));
2571}
2572
2573int
2574pcap_loop(pcap_t *p, int cnt, pcap_handler callback, u_char *user)
2575{
2576 register int n;
2577
2578 for (;;) {
2579 if (p->rfile != NULL) {
2580 /*
2581 * 0 means EOF, so don't loop if we get 0.
2582 */
2583 n = pcap_offline_read(p, cnt, callback, user);
2584 } else {
2585 /*
2586 * XXX keep reading until we get something
2587 * (or an error occurs)
2588 */
2589 do {
2590 n = p->read_op(p, cnt, callback, user);
2591 } while (n == 0);
2592 }
2593 if (n <= 0)
2594 return (n);
2595 if (!PACKET_COUNT_IS_UNLIMITED(cnt)) {
2596 cnt -= n;
2597 if (cnt <= 0)
2598 return (0);
2599 }
2600 }
2601}
2602
2603/*
2604 * Force the loop in "pcap_read()" or "pcap_read_offline()" to terminate.
2605 */
2606void
2607pcap_breakloop(pcap_t *p)
2608{
2609 p->break_loop = 1;
2610}
2611
2612int
2613pcap_datalink(pcap_t *p)
2614{
2615 if (!p->activated)
2616 return (PCAP_ERROR_NOT_ACTIVATED);
2617 return (p->linktype);
2618}
2619
2620int
2621pcap_datalink_ext(pcap_t *p)
2622{
2623 if (!p->activated)
2624 return (PCAP_ERROR_NOT_ACTIVATED);
2625 return (p->linktype_ext);
2626}
2627
2628int
2629pcap_list_datalinks(pcap_t *p, int **dlt_buffer)
2630{
2631 if (!p->activated)
2632 return (PCAP_ERROR_NOT_ACTIVATED);
2633 if (p->dlt_count == 0) {
2634 /*
2635 * We couldn't fetch the list of DLTs, which means
2636 * this platform doesn't support changing the
2637 * DLT for an interface. Return a list of DLTs
2638 * containing only the DLT this device supports.
2639 */
2640 *dlt_buffer = (int*)malloc(sizeof(**dlt_buffer));
2641 if (*dlt_buffer == NULL) {
2642 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(p->errbuf, sizeof(p->errbuf),
2643 errno, "malloc");
2644 return (PCAP_ERROR);
2645 }
2646 **dlt_buffer = p->linktype;
2647 return (1);
2648 } else {
2649 *dlt_buffer = (int*)calloc(sizeof(**dlt_buffer), p->dlt_count);
2650 if (*dlt_buffer == NULL) {
2651 pcap_fmt_errmsg_for_errno(p->errbuf, sizeof(p->errbuf),
2652 errno, "malloc");
2653 return (PCAP_ERROR);
2654 }
2655 (void)memcpy(*dlt_buffer, p->dlt_list,
2656 sizeof(**dlt_buffer) * p->dlt_count);
2657 return (p->dlt_count);
2658 }
2659}
2660
2661/*
2662 * In Windows, you might have a library built with one version of the
2663 * C runtime library and an application built with another version of
2664 * the C runtime library, which means that the library might use one
2665 * version of malloc() and free() and the application might use another
2666 * version of malloc() and free(). If so, that means something
2667 * allocated by the library cannot be freed by the application, so we
2668 * need to have a pcap_free_datalinks() routine to free up the list
2669 * allocated by pcap_list_datalinks(), even though it's just a wrapper
2670 * around free().
2671 */
2672void
2673pcap_free_datalinks(int *dlt_list)
2674{
2675 free(dlt_list);
2676}
2677
2678int
2679pcap_set_datalink(pcap_t *p, int dlt)
2680{
2681 int i;
2682 const char *dlt_name;
2683
2684 if (dlt < 0)
2685 goto unsupported;
2686
2687 if (p->dlt_count == 0 || p->set_datalink_op == NULL) {
2688 /*
2689 * We couldn't fetch the list of DLTs, or we don't
2690 * have a "set datalink" operation, which means
2691 * this platform doesn't support changing the
2692 * DLT for an interface. Check whether the new
2693 * DLT is the one this interface supports.
2694 */
2695 if (p->linktype != dlt)
2696 goto unsupported;
2697
2698 /*
2699 * It is, so there's nothing we need to do here.
2700 */
2701 return (0);
2702 }
2703 for (i = 0; i < p->dlt_count; i++)
2704 if (p->dlt_list[i] == (u_int)dlt)
2705 break;
2706 if (i >= p->dlt_count)
2707 goto unsupported;
2708 if (p->dlt_count == 2 && p->dlt_list[0] == DLT_EN10MB &&
2709 dlt == DLT_DOCSIS) {
2710 /*
2711 * This is presumably an Ethernet device, as the first
2712 * link-layer type it offers is DLT_EN10MB, and the only
2713 * other type it offers is DLT_DOCSIS. That means that
2714 * we can't tell the driver to supply DOCSIS link-layer
2715 * headers - we're just pretending that's what we're
2716 * getting, as, presumably, we're capturing on a dedicated
2717 * link to a Cisco Cable Modem Termination System, and
2718 * it's putting raw DOCSIS frames on the wire inside low-level
2719 * Ethernet framing.
2720 */
2721 p->linktype = dlt;
2722 return (0);
2723 }
2724 if (p->set_datalink_op(p, dlt) == -1)
2725 return (-1);
2726 p->linktype = dlt;
2727 return (0);
2728
2729unsupported:
2730 dlt_name = pcap_datalink_val_to_name(dlt);
2731 if (dlt_name != NULL) {
2732 (void) pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, sizeof(p->errbuf),
2733 "%s is not one of the DLTs supported by this device",
2734 dlt_name);
2735 } else {
2736 (void) pcap_snprintf(p->errbuf, sizeof(p->errbuf),
2737 "DLT %d is not one of the DLTs supported by this device",
2738 dlt);
2739 }
2740 return (-1);
2741}

2745 * together for a case independent comparison. The mappings are
2746 * based upon ascii character sequences.

2800 (u_char)'\354', (u_char)'\355', (u_char)'\356', (u_char)'\357',
2801 (u_char)'\360', (u_char)'\361', (u_char)'\362', (u_char)'\363',
2802 (u_char)'\364', (u_char)'\365', (u_char)'\366', (u_char)'\367',
2803 (u_char)'\370', (u_char)'\371', (u_char)'\372', (u_char)'\333',
2804 (u_char)'\334', (u_char)'\335', (u_char)'\336', (u_char)'\337',
2805 (u_char)'\340', (u_char)'\341', (u_char)'\342', (u_char)'\343',
2806 (u_char)'\344', (u_char)'\345', (u_char)'\346', (u_char)'\347',
2807 (u_char)'\350', (u_char)'\351', (u_char)'\352', (u_char)'\353',
2808 (u_char)'\354', (u_char)'\355', (u_char)'\356', (u_char)'\357',
2809 (u_char)'\360', (u_char)'\361', (u_char)'\362', (u_char)'\363',
2810 (u_char)'\364', (u_char)'\365', (u_char)'\366', (u_char)'\367',
2811 (u_char)'\370', (u_char)'\371', (u_char)'\372', (u_char)'\373',
2812 (u_char)'\374', (u_char)'\375', (u_char)'\376', (u_char)'\377',
2813};
2814
2815int
2816pcap_strcasecmp(const char *s1, const char *s2)
2817{
2818 register const u_char *cm = charmap,
2819 *us1 = (const u_char *)s1,
2820 *us2 = (const u_char *)s2;
2821
2822 while (cm[*us1] == cm[*us2++])
2823 if (*us1++ == '\0')
2824 return(0);
2825 return (cm[*us1] - cm[*--us2]);
2826}

2979int
2980pcap_datalink_name_to_val(const char *name)
2981{
2982 int i;
2983
2984 for (i = 0; dlt_choices[i].name != NULL; i++) {
2985 if (pcap_strcasecmp(dlt_choices[i].name, name) == 0)
2986 return (dlt_choices[i].dlt);
2987 }
2988 return (-1);
2989}
2990
2991const char *
2992pcap_datalink_val_to_name(int dlt)
2993{
2994 int i;
2995
2996 for (i = 0; dlt_choices[i].name != NULL; i++) {
2997 if (dlt_choices[i].dlt == dlt)
2998 return (dlt_choices[i].name);
2999 }
3000 return (NULL);
3001}
3002
3003const char *
3004pcap_datalink_val_to_description(int dlt)
3005{
3006 int i;
3007
3008 for (i = 0; dlt_choices[i].name != NULL; i++) {
3009 if (dlt_choices[i].dlt == dlt)
3010 return (dlt_choices[i].description);
3011 }
3012 return (NULL);
3013}

3139void
3140pcap_perror(pcap_t *p, const char *prefix)
3141{
3142 fprintf(stderr, "%s: %s\n", prefix, p->errbuf);
3143}
